wrong_answer_explanations.C: Fluoromethane is LESS ideal due to larger size and stronger IMFs.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Fluoromethane is larger, not smaller, than N2.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - The Gas Phase: Explain why 'Nitrogen gas is more ideal because it is smaller and forms weaker intermolecular interactions.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: The kinetic molecular theory states that:

options.A: the average kinetic energy of a molecule of gas is directly proportional to the temperature of the gas in kelvin.
options.B: collisions between gas molecules are inelastic.
options.C: gas particles occupy discrete areas of space.
options.D: all gas molecules have the same kinetic energy at the same temperature.

questions.explanation: The average kinetic energy is directly proportional to the temperature of a gas in kelvin. The kinetic molecular theory states that collisions between molecules are elastic and thus do not result in a loss of energy, eliminating (B). Gas particles are assumed to take up negligible space in kinetic molecular theory, eliminating (C). While the average kinetic energy of any gas as a whole is the same at a given temperature, the particles themselves have a distribution of speeds (as seen in the Maxwell–Boltzmann distribution curve), eliminating (D).
questions.short_reason: 'KE proportional to T!' Average kinetic energy equals (3/2)kT. Temperature directly determines molecular motion.

wrong_answer_explanations.B: Collisions are elastic in ideal gases - no energy lost.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Gas particles are assumed to occupy negligible space, not discrete areas.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Molecules have a DISTRIBUTION of speeds - not all the same KE.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - The Gas Phase: Explain why 'the average kinetic energy of a molecule of gas is directly proportional to the temperature of the gas in kelvin.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: The plots of two gases at STP are shown below. One of the gases is 1.0 L of helium, and the other is 1.0 L of bromine. Which plot corresponds to each gas and why?

options.A: Curve A is helium and curve B is bromine because helium has a smaller molar mass than bromine.
options.B: Curve A is helium and curve B is bromine because the average kinetic energy of bromine is greater than the average kinetic energy of helium.
options.C: Curve A is bromine and curve B is helium because helium has a smaller molar mass than bromine.
options.D: Curve A is bromine and curve B is helium because the average kinetic energy of bromine is greater than the average kinetic energy of helium.

questions.explanation: At STP, the difference between the distribution of speeds for helium and bromine gas is due to the difference in molar mass. Helium has a smaller molar mass than bromine. Particles with small masses travel faster than those with large masses, so the helium gas corresponds to curve B, which has a higher average speed. Because the gases are at the same temperature (273 K), they have the same average kinetic energy, eliminating (B) and (D).
questions.short_reason: 'Light = fast!' At same T, lighter molecules (He) have higher average speeds to maintain equal average KE. Curve B is shifted right (faster).

wrong_answer_explanations.A: A is bromine (heavier = slower), B is helium (lighter = faster).
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Reasoning is wrong - KE is equal at same T, not greater for heavier gases.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Both the assignment and reasoning are wrong.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - The Gas Phase: Explain why 'Curve A is bromine and curve B is helium because helium has a smaller molar mass than bromine.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: At sea level and 25°C, the solubility of oxygen gas in water is 1.25 × 10−3 M. In Denver, a city in the United States that lies high above sea level, the atmospheric pressure is 0.800 atm. What is the solubility of oxygen in water in Denver?
questions.explanation: The solubility of gases in liquids is directly proportional to the atmospheric pressure, as shown by Henry’s law. Note that the use of fractions allows this problem to be simplified more readily than it would be with decimals.
questions.short_reason: 'Henry's law: solubility proportional to pressure!' At 0.8 atm, solubility is 0.8 × 1.25 × 10^-3 = 1.0 × 10^-3 M.

wrong_answer_explanations.B: This isn't quite the right calculation for Henry's law.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Higher than sea level value? That's backwards for lower pressure!
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Way too high - pressure is LOWER in Denver, so solubility is LOWER.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - The Gas Phase: Explain why '1.00 × 10−3 M' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Given that the gases at the center of the sun have an average molar mass of 2.00 g mol , compressed to a density of 1.20 g cm 3 under 1.30 × 109 atm of pressure, what is the temperature at the center of the sun?
questions.explanation: The ideal gas law can be modified to include density (ρ) because the number of moles of gas, n, is equal to the mass divided by the molar mass. Thus, P V = n R T = m M R T → P = m V × R T M = ρ R T M . Isolating for temperature gives: T = P M ρ R T = ( 1.3 × 10 9 atm) ( 2 .00 g mol ) ( 1.2 g cm 3 ) ( 1000 cm 3 L= ) ( 0.0821 L · atm mol · K ) ≈ ( 1.3 × 2 × 10 9 ) ( 1 ) ( 1000 ) ( 0 . 1 ) ≈ 2 . 6 × 10 9 100 ≈ 2 . 6 × 10 7 K
questions.short_reason: 'Rearrange ideal gas law with density!' PV = nRT → PM = ρRT → T = PM/ρR. Plug in the extreme values for the sun's core.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Off by factor of 1000 - calculation error in handling large numbers.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Off by factor of 10 - still not quite right.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Off by factor of 1000 in the other direction.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - The Gas Phase: Explain why '2.6 × 107 K' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text:
The gaseous state of matter is characterized by which of the following properties?
I. Gases are compressible.
II. Gases assume the volume of their containers.
III. Gas particles exist as diatomic molecules.
questions.explanation: Gases are easily compressible because they travel freely with large amounts of space between molecules. Because gas particles are far apart from each other and in rapid motion, they tend to take up the volume of their container. Many gases exist as diatomic molecules, but this is not a property that characterizes all gases, eliminating option III.
questions.short_reason: 'Gases expand to fill, and can be squeezed!' These are the defining properties. Not all gases are diatomic (He, Ar, etc.).

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Statement II about filling containers is also true.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Statement I about compressibility is also true.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Statement III is FALSE - many gases are monatomic or polyatomic.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - The Gas Phase: Explain why 'I and II only' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: A gas at a temperature of 27°C has a volume of 60.0 mL. What temperature change is needed to increase this gas to a volume of 90.0 mL?
questions.explanation: We will use Charles’s law. First, we must convert the temperature to kelvin by adding 273 to get 300 K as the initial temperature. Think of this as a proportionality: If the volume is multiplied by 3 2 , the temperature will also have to be multiplied by 3 2 . Thus the final temperature is 450 K, which represents a 150 K increase (which is equivalent to an increase of 150°C).
questions.short_reason: 'Charles's law: V/T = constant!' Going from 60 to 90 mL means T goes from 300 K to 450 K. That's +150 K = +150°C.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Reduction would DECREASE volume, not increase it.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: 13.5°C is way too small a change for 50% volume increase.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Increase is correct, but the magnitude is wrong.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - The Gas Phase: Explain why 'An increase of 150°C' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: How do a significant decrease in temperature and volume affect ideal gas behavior, respectively?

options.A: Both lead to more ideal behavior.
options.B: A lower temperature leads to deviations from ideal behavior, while lower volume causes more ideal behavior.
options.C: A lower temperature leads to more ideal behavior, while lower volume causes more ideal behavior.
options.D: Both lead to deviations in ideal behavior.

questions.explanation: A decrease in temperature leads to a decrease in the kinetic energy of the particles so intermolecular interactions become more significant. This change leads to deviations from ideal behavior. Similarly, decreases in volume cause the volume of the particles themselves to become significant. This change also leads to deviations from ideal behavior. Thus, (D) is correct.
questions.short_reason: 'Cold + cramped = deviations!' Both low T (more IMF effect) and low V (particle size matters) cause non-ideal behavior.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Both conditions cause DEviations, not ideal behavior.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Both conditions cause deviations - neither leads to more ideal behavior.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Lower temperature definitely causes deviations, not ideal behavior.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - The Gas Phase: Explain why 'Both lead to deviations in ideal behavior.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: In which of the following situations is it impossible to predict how the pressure will change for a gas sample?

options.A: The gas is cooled at a constant volume.
options.B: The gas is heated at a constant volume.
options.C: The gas is heated, and the volume is simultaneously increased.
options.D: The gas is cooled, and the volume is simultaneously increased.

questions.explanation: Both a change in temperature and a change in volume can affect a gas’s pressure. So if one of those two variables is kept constant, as in (A) and (B), we’ll definitely be able to predict which way the pressure will change. At a constant volume, heating the gas will increase its pressure, and cooling the gas will decrease it. What about when both temperature and volume are changing? If both changes have the same effect on pressure, then we can still predict which way it will change. This is the case in (D). Cooling the gas and increasing its volume both decrease pressure. (C), on the other hand, presents too vague a scenario for us to predict definitively the change in pressure. Heating the gas would amplify the pressure, while increasing the volume would decrease it. Without knowing the magnitude of each influence, it’s impossible to say whether the pressure would increase, decrease, or stay the same.
questions.short_reason: 'Opposing effects = uncertain outcome!' Heating increases P, but increasing V decreases P. Without magnitudes, we can't say which wins.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Predictable - cooling at constant V always decreases P.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Predictable - heating at constant V always increases P.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Predictable - both changes decrease P, so it definitely decreases.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - The Gas Phase: Explain why 'The gas is heated, and the volume is simultaneously increased.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Experimenters notice that the molar concentration of dissolved oxygen in an enclosed water tank has decreased to one-half its original value. In an attempt to counter this decrease, they quadruple the partial pressure of oxygen in the container. What is the final concentration of the gas?

options.B: The same as the original concentration

questions.explanation: Initially the concentration of the gas is decreased to one-half its original value. Recall that concentration (solubility) and partial pressure are directly related—as one increases, the other increases. If the experimenters then quadruple the partial pressure of oxygen in the vessel, the solubility is also increased by a factor of four. One-half times four gives twice the original concentration value. Misreading the answer choices as being related to the concentration before the experimenters increased the partial pressure leads to (D).
questions.short_reason: 'Henry's law again!' Start at 1/2 original, multiply by 4 (quadruple pressure) = 2× original concentration.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: This is where we started after the decrease - didn't account for the pressure increase.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: This would mean the pressure increase exactly offset the decrease.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: This would mean the pressure increase multiplied the ORIGINAL, not the decreased value.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - The Gas Phase: Explain why 'Double the original concentration' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: An aqueous solution was prepared by mixing 70 g of an unknown nondissociating solute into 100 g of water. The solution has a boiling point of 101.0°C. What is the molar mass of the solute? (Note: K b = 0.512 K · kg mol )
questions.explanation: The equation ΔTb = iKbm can be used to solve this problem. The change in boiling point is 101.0 − 100 = 1.0°C. Then, plug that into: Δ T b = i K b m → m = Δ T b i K b = 1. 0 K ( 1 ) ( 0.512 K · kg mol ) ≈ 2 m The van’t Hoff factor for this solute is 1 because the molecule does not dissociate into smaller components. Then, convert to grams of solute using the definition of molality: molality = moles of solute kg of solvent → moles of solute = ( 2 m ) ( 0.1 kg) = 0.2 mol . The mass used in this equation is 0.1 kg because 100 mL of water has a mass of 0.1 kg. Then, determine the molar mass: molar mass = 70 g 0.2 mol = 350 g mol , which is closest to (A).
questions.short_reason: 'ΔT = iKm' rearranged! 1°C = (1)(0.512)(m), so m = 2. Then 70g in 0.1kg = 0.2mol, giving MM = 350 g/mol.

wrong_answer_explanations.B: Way too low - would require much higher molality.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Calculation error in the mole conversion.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: This is close to 2× the molar mass - doubled somewhere.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Solutions: Explain why '358 . 4 g mol' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text:
Which phases of solvent and solute can form a solution?
I. Solid solvent, gaseous solute
II. Solid solvent, solid solute
III. Gaseous solvent, gaseous solute
questions.explanation: All three choices can make a solution as long as the two components create a mixture that is of uniform appearance (homogeneous). Hydrogen in platinum is an example of a gas in a solid. Brass and steel are examples of homogeneous mixtures of solids. The air we breathe is an example of a homogeneous mixture of gases; while these are more commonly referred to as mixtures, they still fit the criteria of a solution.
questions.short_reason: 'Solutions = homogeneous mixtures of anything!' Gas in solid (H2 in Pt), solid in solid (alloys), gas in gas (air) - all count.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Statement III is also true - gases mix completely.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Statement II is also true - alloys are solid solutions.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Statement I is also true - gas can dissolve in solid.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Solutions: Explain why 'I, II, and III' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Two organic liquids, pictured in the figure below, are combined to form a solution. Based on their structures, will the solution closely obey Raoult’s law?

options.A: Yes; the liquids differ due to the additional methyl group on toluene and, therefore, will not deviate from Raoult’s law.
options.B: Yes; the liquids are very similar and, therefore, will not deviate from Raoult’s law.
options.C: No; the liquids differ due to the additional methyl group on toluene and, therefore, will deviate from Raoult’s law.
options.D: No; the liquids both contain benzene rings, which will interact with each other and cause deviation from Raoult’s law.

questions.explanation: Benzene and toluene are both organic liquids and have very similar properties. They are both nonpolar and are almost exactly the same size. Raoult’s law states that ideal solution behavior is observed when solute–solute, solvent–solvent, and solute–solvent interactions are all very similar. Therefore, benzene and toluene in solution will be predicted to behave as a nearly ideal solution.
questions.short_reason: 'Like dissolves like - closely!' Benzene and toluene are both nonpolar aromatics. Nearly identical properties = nearly ideal solution.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: The methyl group difference is minor - they're still very similar overall.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: The methyl group difference is minor and causes minimal deviation.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Similar benzene rings is a reason they DON'T deviate much, not why they would.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Solutions: Explain why 'Yes; the liquids are very similar and, therefore, will not deviate from Raoult’s law.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following explanations best describes the mechanism by which solute particles affect the melting point of ice?

options.A: Melting point is elevated because the kinetic energy of the substance increases.
options.B: Melting point is elevated because the kinetic energy of the substance decreases.
options.C: Melting point is depressed because solute particles interfere with lattice formation.
options.D: Melting point is depressed because solute particles enhance lattice formation.

questions.explanation: Melting point depresses upon solute addition, making (A) and (B) incorrect. Solute particles interfere with lattice formation, the highly organized state in which solid molecules align themselves. Colder-than-normal conditions are necessary to create the solid structure.
questions.short_reason: 'Solute disrupts crystal packing!' Particles get in the way of forming the organized solid lattice, requiring colder conditions to freeze.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Melting point is LOWERED (depressed), not elevated.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Kinetic energy of substance doesn't directly explain lattice disruption.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Solutes INTERFERE with lattice formation, they don't enhance it.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Solutions: Explain why 'Melting point is depressed because solute particles interfere with lattice formation.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: The process of formation of a salt solution can be better understood by breaking the process into three steps:   Which of the following correctly lists the enthalpy changes for these three steps, respectively?
questions.explanation: The first step will most likely be endothermic because energy is required to break molecules apart. The second step is also endothermic because the intermolecular forces in the solvent must be overcome to allow incorporation of solute particles. The third step will most likely be exothermic because polar water molecules will interact with the dissolved ions, creating a stable solution and releasing energy.
questions.short_reason: 'Break, break, form!' Breaking solute bonds costs energy (endo), breaking solvent bonds costs energy (endo), but solvation releases energy (exo).

wrong_answer_explanations.A: First step (breaking solute) is ENDOthermic, not EXOthermic.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Both breaking steps are endothermic - exothermic first step is wrong.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Third step (solvation) is EXOthermic due to favorable ion-dipole interactions.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Solutions: Explain why 'Endothermic, endothermic, exothermic' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: The entropy change when a solution forms can be expressed by the term ΔS°soln. When water molecules become ordered around an ion as it dissolves, the ordering would be expected to make a negative contribution to ΔS°soln. An ion that has more charge density will have a greater hydration effect, or ordering of water molecules. In an experiment, an equimolar amount of each of the following aqueous soluble compounds is dissolved in its own test tube containing 100 mL of water. Which will have the most negative contribution to ΔS°soln? (Assume that the charge density of each ion is equal to its actual charge.)
questions.explanation: BeF2 will cause the most negative contribution to ΔS°soln through the hydration effect because Be2+ cation has the highest charge density compared to the other ions. All of the other ions have a charge density of +1 or –1, whereas Be2+ has a charge density of magnitude two.
questions.short_reason: 'More charge = more ordering!' Be2+ has the highest charge density, creating the strongest ordering of water molecules = most negative entropy contribution.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: K+ and Cl- are only +1/-1 charges - less water ordering than Be2+.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Cs+ and I- are large monovalent ions - very little water ordering.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Na+ and Cl- are also +1/-1 - less ordering than the dipositive Be2+.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Solutions: Explain why 'BeF2' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: When ammonia, NH3, is used as a solvent, it can form complex ions. For example, dissolving AgCl in NH3 will result in the complex ion [Ag(NH3)]2+. What effect would the formation of complex ions have on the solubility of a compound like AgCl in NH3?

options.A: The solubility of AgCl will increase because complex ion formation will cause more ions to exist in solution, which interact with AgCl to cause it to dissociate.
options.B: The solubility of AgCl will increase because complex ion formation will consume Ag+ ions and cause the equilibrium to shift away from solid AgCl.
options.C: The solubility of AgCl will decrease because Ag+ ions are in complexes, and the Ag+ ions that are not complexed will associate with Cl− to form solid AgCl.
options.D: The solubility of AgCl will decrease because complex ion formation will consume Ag+ ions and cause the equilibrium to shift toward the solid AgCl.

questions.explanation: Formation of complex ions between silver ions and ammonia will cause more molecules of solid AgCl to dissociate. The equilibrium is driven toward dissociation because the Ag+ ions are essentially being removed from solution when they complex with ammonia. This rationale is based upon Le Châtelier’s principle, stating that when a chemical equilibrium experiences a change in concentration, the system will shift to counteract that change.
questions.short_reason: 'Le Chatelier with complex ions!' Removing Ag+ by complexation shifts AgCl dissolution to the right, dissolving more solid.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: More ions in solution don't directly cause AgCl to dissolve - it's the equilibrium shift.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Solubility INCREASES because Ag+ is removed from equilibrium.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Consuming Ag+ shifts equilibrium AWAY from solid, not toward it.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Solutions: Explain why 'The solubility of AgCl will increase because complex ion formation will consume Ag+ ions and cause the equilibrium to shift away from solid AgCl.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: One hundred grams of sucrose are dissolved in a cup of hot water at 80°C. The cup of water contains 300.00 mL of water. What is the percent composition by mass of sugar in the resulting solution? (Note: Sucrose = C12H22O11, density of water at 80 ° C = 0.975 g mL )
questions.explanation: The mass percent of a solute equals the mass of the solute divided by the mass of the total solution times 100%. mass % = mass of solute total mass of solution ×100%. Plug in the values given for sucrose, the volume of water and the density of water to determine the % mass of sucrose: 100 g sucrose ( 300 mL H 2 O ) ( 0 . 975 g/mL ) + 100 g sucrose × 100 % ≈ 100 300 + 100 × 100 % = 100 400 × 100 % = 25 % Keep in mind that in rounding while calculating, the denominator was estimated to be larger than the actual value, thus giving an answer that is slightly lower than the actual value. Thus, the correct answer is (B), 25.5%. (A) results if rounding error is not taken into account. While these answers are very close, the mass of the water must be slightly less than 300 g, given the density value, so the percent composition of sucrose must be slightly higher than 25%. If the solute’s mass is not added to the solvent’s, the calculated value is 34.2%, which is (D). (C) neglects both the addition step and the rounding error.
questions.short_reason: 'Mass % = solute/(solute + solution) × 100!' 100g sugar in (100g + 292.5g water) = 25.5%. Account for water's density!

wrong_answer_explanations.A: 25% ignores that water density isn't exactly 1.00 g/mL at 80°C.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: 33% forgets to add solute mass to the denominator.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: 34.2% makes both errors - wrong density and wrong formula.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Solutions: Explain why '25.5%' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following combinations of liquids would be expected to have a vapor pressure higher than the vapor pressure that would be predicted by Raoult’s law?
questions.explanation: Mixtures that have a higher vapor pressure than predicted by Raoult’s law have stronger solvent–solvent and solute–solute interactions than solvent–solute interactions. Therefore, particles do not want to stay in solution and more readily evaporate, creating a higher vapor pressure than an ideal solution. Two liquids that have different properties, like hexane (hydrophobic) and ethanol (hydrophilic, small) in (A), would not have many interactions with each other and would cause positive deviation (i.e. higher vapor pressure). (B) and (C) are composed of liquids that are similar to one another and would not show significant deviation from Raoult’s law. (D) contains two liquids that would interact very well with each other, which would actually cause a negative deviation from Raoult’s law—when attracted to one other, solutes and solvents prefer to stay in liquid form and have a lower vapor pressure than predicted by Raoult’s law.
questions.short_reason: 'Unlike repel = positive deviation!' Ethanol (polar, H-bonding) and hexane (nonpolar) don't mix well - they'd rather escape to vapor phase.

wrong_answer_explanations.B: Acetone and water can H-bond - they'd have negative deviation if anything.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Both alcohols can H-bond with each other - minimal deviation expected.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: HNO3 and water mix extremely well - negative deviation (lower VP).

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Solutions: Explain why 'Ethanol and hexane' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: The salt KCl is dissolved in a beaker. To an observer holding the beaker, the solution begins to feel colder as the KCl dissolves. From this observation, one could conclude that:

options.A: ΔS°soln is large enough to overcome the unfavorable ΔH°soln.
options.B: KCl is mostly insoluble in water.
options.C: ΔS°soln must be negative when KCl dissolves.
options.D: boiling point depression will occur in this solution.

questions.explanation: Dissolution is governed by enthalpy and entropy, which are related by the equation ΔG°soln = ΔH°soln − TΔS°soln. The cooling of the solution indicates that heat is used up in this bond-breaking reaction. In other words, dissolution is endothermic, and ΔH is positive. The reaction is occurring spontaneously, so ΔG must be negative. The only way that a positive ΔH can result in a negative ΔG is if entropy, ΔS, is a large, positive value as in (A). Conceptually, that means that the only way the solid can dissolve is if the increase in entropy is great enough to overcome the increase in enthalpy. (B) is incorrect because it is clearly stated in the question stem that KCl dissolves; further, all salts of Group 1 metals are soluble. (C) is incorrect because ΔS°soln must be positive in order for KCl to dissolve. Finally, (D) is incorrect because solute dissolution would cause the boiling point to elevate, not depress. It is also not a piece of evidence that could be found simply by observing the beaker’s temperature change.
questions.short_reason: 'Cold means endothermic!' If dissolving feels cold, heat is absorbed (positive ΔH). For this to be spontaneous, entropy increase must overcome it.

wrong_answer_explanations.B: KCl clearly dissolves (question says so) - it's definitely soluble.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: ΔS must be POSITIVE (large enough) to overcome unfavorable ΔH.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Adding solute always RAISES boiling point (elevation, not depression).

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Solutions: Explain why 'ΔS°soln is large enough to overcome the unfavorable ΔH°soln.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following will cause the greatest increase in the boiling point of water when it is dissolved in 1.00 kg H2O?
questions.explanation: The equation to determine the change in boiling point of a solution is as follows: ΔTb = iKbm. m is the molality of the solution, and Kb is the boiling point elevation constant. In this case, the solvent is always water, so Kb will be the same for each solution. What is needed is the number of dissociated particles from each of the original species. This is referred to as the van’t Hoff factor (i) and is multiplied by molality to give a normality (the concentration of the species of interest—in this case, all particles). The normality values determine which species causes the greatest change in boiling point. The choice is between iron(III) nitrate and acetic acid. The fact that acetic acid is a weak acid indicates that only a few particles will dissociate into H+ and acetate. Therefore, the normality of the acetic acid will be much closer to 1.0 than 2.0.
questions.short_reason: 'Count the particles!' Fe(NO3)3 gives 4 particles (1 Fe3+ + 3 NO3-), and 0.5 mol × 4 = 2.0 mol particles - the most!

wrong_answer_explanations.A: CaSO4 dissociates but may not fully (Ksp is low for sulfates).
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Acetic acid is weak - it barely dissociates, so i ≈ 1.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Sucrose doesn't dissociate at all (i = 1, covalent).

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Solutions: Explain why '0.5 mol iron(III) nitrate' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Reverse osmosis is a process that allows fresh water to be obtained by using pressure to force an impure water source through a semi-permeable membrane that only allows water molecules to pass. What is the minimum pressure that would be required to purify seawater at 25°C that has a total osmolarity of 1,000 mOsm/L?
questions.explanation: Osmotic pressure is given by the formula Π = i M R T . Entering the values from the question stem gives: Π = ( 1000 × 10 - 3 mOsm/L)(0.0812 L·atm/mol·K)(298 K) ≈ 1 × 0 . 08 × 300 = 24 atm actual value = 24.2 atm Notice that the concentration of seawater is given for all solutes, which represents i×M. It is also given in mOsm/L, which is converted to moles per liter by multiplying by 10-3. Also, the question asks for the minimum pressure required, which means that the correct answer choice must be slightly above the calculated pressure in order for reverse osmosis to proceed.
questions.short_reason: 'Π = iMRT' rearranged! 1000 mOsm/L = 1 M osmoles. Π = (1)(0.0821)(298) ≈ 24.5 atm. Need slightly MORE to reverse osmosis.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: 23.5 is the calculated osmotic pressure - need MORE to reverse, so 24.5 minimum.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Way too high - units error likely (didn't convert mOsm to M).
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Same issue - didn't convert units properly.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Solutions: Explain why '24.5 atm' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Lead is a toxic element that can cause many symptoms, including intellectual disabilities in children. If a body of water is polluted with lead ions at 200 ppb (parts per billion), what is the concentration of lead expressed as molarity? (Note: The density of water is 1 g mL , and ppb = grams per 109 grams of solution)
questions.explanation: 200 ppb of Pb2+ is equivalent to 200 grams of Pb2+ in 109 grams of solution; given the extremely low concentration of lead, the mass of the water can be assumed to be approximately 109 grams, as well. To solve, set up a dimensional analysis question. The units needed at the end are moles per liter (molarity), so convert from grams of lead to moles of lead and grams of water to liters of water: [ 200 g Pb 2 + 10 9 g H 2 O ] [ 10 3 g H 2 O 1 L ] [ 1 mol Pb 2 + 207.2 g Pb 2 + ] ≈ 200 × 10 3 200 × 10 9 = 1 × 10 − 6 M = 10 × 10 - 7 M ( actual value = 9 . 67 × 10 - 7 M ) Note that the denominator was rounded to a smaller number, meaning the estimated answer is slightly larger than the actual value.
questions.short_reason: 'ppb to molarity!' 200 g Pb per 10^9 g solution. Convert g to mol (÷207), convert g H2O to L (÷1000). Result: 10^-6 M.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Off by factor of 1000 - likely forgot to convert billion to million somewhere.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: This is the molarity answer, but units are g/L in question.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Off by factor of 10 - calculation error.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Solutions: Explain why '9.7 × 10−7 M Pb2+' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: A saturated solution of aqueous cobalt(III) hydroxide (Ksp = 1.6 × 10−44) is added to a saturated solution of aqueous thallium(III) hydroxide (Ksp = 6.3 × 10−46). What is likely to occur?

options.A: Both cobalt(III) hydroxide and thallium(III) hydroxide remain stable in solution.
options.B: Thallium(III) hydroxide precipitates and cobalt(III) hydroxide remains stable in solution.
options.C: Cobalt(III) hydroxide precipitates and thallium(III) hydroxide remains stable in solution.
options.D: Both thallium(III) hydroxide and cobalt(III) hydroxide precipitate.

questions.explanation: This question is actually more complicated than it seems since hydroxide is involved. In aqueous solution, the concentration of hydroxide from the autoionization of water is 10–7 M. This concentration is significantly greater (approximately 10,000× greater) than the amount of hydroxide that would be produced by the dissociation of either salt. Thus, the concentration of hydroxide is set by water, not by the dissociation of cobalt(III) hydroxide and thallium(III) hydroxide. When the two solutions are mixed, the concentration of hydroxide does not change. However, in mixing the two solutions, the concentration of the metal ions decreases as a consequence of dilution. As a result, both solutions would be below saturation, justifying (A) as the correct answer.
questions.short_reason: 'Dilution drops concentration!' Mixing the solutions dilutes both metal ions. Since [OH-] is set by water, both remain undersaturated.

wrong_answer_explanations.B: Tl(OH)3 doesn't precipitate because Tl3+ is diluted below saturation.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Co(OH)3 doesn't precipitate because Co3+ is diluted below saturation.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Neither precipitates - both become undersaturated upon dilution.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Solutions: Explain why 'Both cobalt(III) hydroxide and thallium(III) hydroxide remain stable in solution.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: The following equilibrium exists when AgBr (Ksp = 5.35 × 10−13) is in solution:  AgBr (s) ⇌ Ag+ (aq) + Br− (aq)  What is the solubility of AgBr in a solution of 0.0010 M NaBr?
questions.explanation: The solubility of AgBr can be determined using the Ksp value given in the equation. Some amount of AgBr will dissolve; this is the molar solubility x for these conditions. When AgBr dissociates, there will be x amount of silver(I) formed and x amount of bromide—which is added to the 0.0010 M Br- already present from NaBr. AgBr ⇌ Ag + + Br − K sp = [ Ag + ] [ Br − ] 5 . 35 × 10 − 13 = ( x ) ( 0.0010 M + x ) Given the Ksp of 5.4 × 10–13, x will be negligible compared to 0.0010 M. Thus, the math can be simplified to: 5 . 35 × 10 - 13 = ( x ) ( 0 . 0010 ) x = 5 . 35 × 10 - 13 10 - 3 = 5 . 35 × 10 - 10 Therefore, x, the molar solubility, is 5.35 × 10−10, which looks like (C). However, the units of the answer choices are grams per liter, not molarity, and the result must be multiplied by the molar mass ( 187.8 g mol ) : 5 . 35 × 10 − 10 mol L × 187.8 g mol ≈ 5 × 10 − 10 × 200 = 1 , 000 × 10 − 10 = 1 × 10 − 7 which is close to (D). Note that a very accurate approximation was reached by rounding down the first number and rounding up the second, balancing the error.
questions.short_reason: 'Common ion effect!' The 0.001 M Br- from NaBr suppresses AgBr dissolution. Solve Ksp with [Br-] = 0.001 M, then convert to g/L.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: This is Ksp itself - not the molar solubility.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Calculation error in the common ion setup.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: This is molar solubility (M) - forgot to multiply by molar mass for g/L.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Solutions: Explain why '1. 04 × 10 − 7 g L' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is not a Brønsted–Lowry base?
questions.explanation: A Brønsted–Lowry base is defined as a proton acceptor. Ammonia, fluoride, and water— (A), (B), and (C), respectively—each accept a proton. (D), HNO2, is a far better Brønsted–Lowry acid, donating a proton to a solution.
questions.short_reason: 'Bronsted base accepts protons!' HNO2 is an acid (gives away H+). The others (NH3, F-, H2O) can all accept protons.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Ammonia accepts H+ to become NH4+ - definitely a Bronsted base.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Fluoride accepts H+ to become HF - also a Bronsted base.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Water accepts H+ to become H3O+ - amphoteric but can act as base.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Acids and Bases: Explain why 'HNO₂ (nitrous acid)' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is closest to the pH of a solution containing 5 mM H2SO4?
questions.explanation: First, convert the concentration to 5 × 10−3 M. Next, because sulfuric acid is a strong acid, we can assume that, for the majority of sulfuric acid molecules (although not all), both protons will dissociate. The concentration of hydrogen ions is therefore 2 × 5 × 10−3, or 10−2. The equation for pH is pH = −log [H+]. If [H+] = 10−2 M, then pH = 2.
questions.short_reason: 'H2SO4 is diprotic!' 5 mM × 2 = 10 mM = 10^-2 M H+. pH = -log(10^-2) = 2.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: pH = 1 would mean [H+] = 0.1 M - we have 0.01 M.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: pH = 3 would mean only 1 mM H+, forgetting the diprotic nature.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: pH = 4 would be way too basic for 5 mM strong acid.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Acids and Bases: Explain why '2' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following represents chloric acid?
questions.explanation: Answering this question is simply a matter of knowing nomenclature. Acids ending in –ic are derivatives of anions ending in –ate, while acids ending in –ous are derivatives of anions ending in –ite. ClO3−, (B), is chlorate because it has more oxygen than the other commonly occurring ion, ClO2−, which is named chlorite. Therefore, HClO3 is chloric acid. HClO2, (C), represents chlorous acid. HClO, (D), represents hypochlorous acid.
questions.short_reason: 'Chloric from chlorate!' -ic acid comes from -ate anion. ClO3- is chlorate (more O), so HClO3 is chloric acid.

wrong_answer_explanations.B: ClO3- is the anion (chlorate), not the acid.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: HClO2 is chlorOUS acid (from chlorite).
wrong_answer_explanations.D: HClO is hypochlorous acid (least oxygens).

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Acids and Bases: Explain why 'HClO3' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following bases is the weakest?
questions.explanation: Soluble hydroxides of Group IA and IIA metals are strong bases, eliminating (A) and (D). (B) and (C) are both weak bases; however, methylamine contains an alkyl group, which is electron-donating. This increases the electron density on the nitrogen in methylamine, making it a stronger (Lewis) base. Therefore, ammonia is the weakest base.
questions.short_reason: 'Ammonia has no alkyl boost!' CH3NH2 has an electron-donating methyl group that increases N's electron density. Plain NH3 is the weaker base.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: KOH is a strong base (complete dissociation) - much stronger than NH3.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Methylamine is stronger than ammonia due to electron donation from CH3.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Ca(OH)2 is also a strong base - much stronger than NH3.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Acids and Bases: Explain why 'NH3' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: The function of a buffer is to:

options.B: resist changes in pH when small amounts of acid or base are added.
options.C: slow down reactions between acids and bases.
options.D: speed up reactions between acids and bases.

questions.explanation: The purpose of a buffer is to resist changes in the pH of a reaction. Buffers are not generally used to affect the kinetics of a reaction, so (C) and (D) are incorrect. (A) is true only in specific circumstances where the pH of the buffer solution itself is neutral. Many natural buffer systems maintain pH in the acidic or basic ranges.
questions.short_reason: 'Buffers resist pH change!' They absorb added acid or base through equilibrium shifts. They don't have to be neutral - blood is buffered at pH 7.4!

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Buffers can maintain any pH where buffer capacity exists, not just neutral.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Buffers don't slow reactions - they're about equilibrium position, not kinetics.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Buffers don't speed up acid-base reactions - they moderate pH changes.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Acids and Bases: Explain why 'resist changes in pH when small amounts of acid or base are added.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: What is the pH of a solution with an ammonium concentration of 70 mM and an ammonia concentration of 712 mM? (Note: The pKb of ammonia is 3.45.)
questions.explanation: The question is asking for pH, but because of the information given, we must first find the pOH and then subtract it from 14 to get the pH. Use the Henderson–Hasselbalch equation: pOH = p K b + log [ conjugate acid] [ base] = 3.45 + log 70 m M 712 m M ≈ 3.45 + log 1 10 = 3.45 − 1 = 2.45 If the pOH = 2.45, the pH = 14 − 2.45 = 11.55.
questions.short_reason: 'Henderson-Hasselbalch for bases!' pOH = pKb + log([BH+]/[B]) = 3.45 + log(70/712) ≈ 3.45 - 1 = 2.45. pH = 14 - 2.45 = 11.55.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: 2.45 is the pOH, not the pH!
wrong_answer_explanations.B: 4.45 adds 1 to pKb incorrectly - ratio is less than 1, so we subtract.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: 9.55 would be pH if pOH was 4.45 - both calculations wrong.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Acids and Bases: Explain why '11.55' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: What is the approximate value of p K a1 ?
questions.explanation: The first pKa in this curve can be estimated by eye. It is located halfway between the starting point (when no base had yet been added) and the first equivalence point (the first steep portion of the graph, around 15 mL). This point is at approximately 7–8 mL on the x-axis, which corresponds to a pH of approximately 1.9. Notice that this region experiences very little change in pH, which is the defining characteristic of a buffer region.
questions.short_reason: 'pKa at half-equivalence!' Halfway to first equivalence point, [HA] = [A-], so pH = pKa1 ≈ 1.9 on this graph.

wrong_answer_explanations.B: 2.9 is too high for the first half-equivalence point on this curve.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: 3.8 is closer to pKa2 region - past the first equivalence point.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: 4.1 is approximately pKa2, not pKa1.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Acids and Bases: Explain why '1.9' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: At what pH is the second equivalence point?
questions.explanation: The second equivalence point is the midpoint of the second steep increase in slope. This corresponds to approximately pH = 5.9.
questions.short_reason: 'Equivalence = steepest slope!' The second equivalence point is at the midpoint of the second steep rise, around pH 5.9.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: pH 3.0 is before the second equivalence point - still in buffer region.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: pH 4.1 is at pKa2, the half-equivalence point, not equivalence.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: pH 7.2 is past the second equivalence point.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Acids and Bases: Explain why 'pH = 5.9' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: What is the approximate value of pKa2?
questions.explanation: The value of the second pKa is found at the midpoint between the first and second equivalence points. In this curve, that corresponds to pH = 4.1. Just like the first pKa, it is in the center of a flat buffering region.
questions.short_reason: 'pKa2 at second half-equivalence!' Halfway between first and second equivalence points, pH = pKa2 ≈ 4.1.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: 3.6 is too early - still in the first buffer region.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: 5.5 is past pKa2, approaching the second equivalence point.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: 7.2 is past the second equivalence point entirely.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Acids and Bases: Explain why '4.1' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: What is the gram equivalent weight of phosphoric acid?
questions.explanation: Gram equivalent weight is the weight (in grams) that releases 1 acid or base equivalent from a compound. Because H3PO4 contains 3 protons, we find the gram equivalent weight by dividing the mass of one mole of the species by 3. The molar mass of phosphoric acid is 98 g mol , so the gram equivalent weight is 32.7 g.
questions.short_reason: 'Three protons = divide by three!' H3PO4 has MW = 98 g/mol. Gram equivalent weight = 98/3 = 32.7 g.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: 24.5 would be dividing by 4 - but phosphoric acid has only 3 protons.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: 49 g is dividing by 2 - that's for diprotic acids, not triprotic.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: 98 g is the full molar mass - didn't divide at all.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Acids and Bases: Explain why '32.7 g' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: What is the [H3O+] of a 2 M aqueous solution of a weak acid HXO2 with Ka = 3.2 × 10−5?
questions.explanation: This question requires the application of the acid dissociation constant. Weak acids do not dissociate completely; therefore, all three species that appear in the balanced equation will be present in solution. Hydrogen ions and conjugate base anions dissociate in equal amounts, so [H+] = [XO2−]. If the initial concentration of HXO2 was 2 M and some amount x dissociates, we will have x amount of H3O+ and XO2− at equilibrium, with 2 M − x amount of HXO2 at equilibrium. K a = [ H 3 O + ] [ XO 2 − ] [ HXO 2 ] = ( x ) ( x ) 2 M − x ≈ x 2 2 Note that x was considered negligible when added or subtracted, per usual. Solving for x, we get: x 2 2 = 3.2 × 10 − 5 → x 2 = 6.4 × 10 − 5 = 64 × 10 − 6 → x = 8 × 10 − 3 M
questions.short_reason: 'Weak acid equilibrium!' Set up Ka = x^2/(2-x) ≈ x^2/2. Solve: x = √(6.4×10^-5) = 8×10^-3 M.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: This is Ka × concentration - forgot to take square root.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Calculation error - wrong square root value.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: This would be the answer if Ka were 10^-5 instead of 3.2×10^-5.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Acids and Bases: Explain why '8.0 × 10−3 M' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: A solution is prepared with an unknown concentration of a theoretical compound with a Ka of exactly 1.0. What is the pH of this solution?

options.D: There is not enough information to answer the question.

questions.explanation: A higher Ka implies a stronger acid. Weak acids usually have a Ka that is several orders of magnitude below 1. The pKa of a compound is the pH at which there are equal concentrations of acid and conjugate base; the pKa of this compound would be −log 1 = 0. With such a low pKa, this compound must be an acid. Therefore, the pH of any concentration of this compound must be below 7.
questions.short_reason: 'Ka = 1 means pKa = 0!' This is a very strong acid. Any concentration will give pH well below 7.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: pH > 7 would mean basic - but Ka = 1 indicates strong acid.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: pH = 7 would require a neutral solution, but this is an acid.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: We CAN determine it's acidic - Ka > 10^-7 always means acid.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Acids and Bases: Explain why 'Less than 7' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of an amphoteric species?

options.A: Amphoteric species can act as an acid or a base, depending on its environment.
options.B: Amphoteric species can act as an oxidizing or reducing agent, depending on its environment.

questions.explanation: An amphoteric species is one that can act either as an acid or a base, depending on its environment. Proton transfers are classic oxidation–reduction reactions, so (A) and (B) are true. (C) is true because many amphoteric species, such as water and bicarbonate, can either donate or accept a proton. (D) is false, and thus the correct answer because amphoteric species can be either polar or nonpolar in nature.
questions.short_reason: 'Amphoteric means versatile, not nonpolar!' Amphoteric species can be polar (like water) - polarity is about charge distribution, not acid-base behavior.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: True - amphoteric species can act as acid OR base depending on partner.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: True - accepting/donating protons involves electron transfer (redox).
wrong_answer_explanations.C: True - many amphoteric species (H2O, HCO3-) can donate or accept H+.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Acids and Bases: Explain why 'Amphoteric species are always nonpolar.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: What is the approximate pH of a 1.2 × 10−5 M aqueous solution of NaOH?
questions.explanation: NaOH is a strong base; as such, there will be 1.2 × 10−5 M OH− in solution. Based on this information alone, the pOH must be between 4 and 5, and the pH must be between 9 and 10. Using the shortcut, pOH ≈ 5 − 0.12 = 4.88. pH = 14 − pOH = 9.12 (actual = 9.08).
questions.short_reason: 'Strong base, direct calculation!' pOH = -log(1.2×10^-5) ≈ 5 - 0.08 = 4.92. pH = 14 - 4.92 = 9.08.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: 4.92 is the pOH, not the pH! Common mistake.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: 7.50 would mean nearly neutral - but we added strong base.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: 12.45 would require much higher concentration of NaOH.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Acids and Bases: Explain why '9.08' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: How many liters of 2 M Ba(OH)2 are needed to titrate a 4 L solution of 6 M H3PO4?
questions.explanation: Use the equivalence point equation: NaVa = NbVb. Ba(OH)2 can dissociate to give two hydroxide ions, so its normality is 2 M × 2 = 4 N. H3PO4 can dissociate to give three hydronium ions, so its normality is 6 M × 3 = 18 N. Plugging into the equation, we get (18 N)(4 L) = (4 N)(Vb). Therefore, Vb is 18 L.
questions.short_reason: 'Equivalence with normalities!' N1V1 = N2V2. Ba(OH)2 is 2×2 = 4N, H3PO4 is 6×3 = 18N. Solve: (18)(4) = (4)(V2), V2 = 18 L.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: 1.33 L uses molarity directly without considering multiple protons/hydroxides.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: 12 L forgets to account for Ba(OH)2 being dibasic.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: 56 L uses wrong normality calculations.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Acids and Bases: Explain why '18 L' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Consider the following equation: 6 Na (s) + 2 NH3 (aq) → 2 Na3N (s) + 3 H2 (g)  Which species acts as an oxidizing agent?
questions.explanation: The oxidizing agent is the species that is reduced in any given equation. In this problem, six hydrogen atoms with +1 oxidation states in NH3 are reduced to three neutral H2 molecules.
questions.short_reason: 'Oxidizing agent gets reduced!' The H in NH3 goes from +1 to 0 (in H2), gaining electrons = being reduced = oxidizing agent.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Na is OXIDIZED (0 to +1 in Na3N) - it's the REDUCING agent.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: N in NH3 goes from -3 to -3 in Na3N - no change, not the oxidizing agent.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: H2 is a product - we're looking at REACTANTS for oxidizing/reducing agents.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Oxidation–reduction Reactions: Explain why 'H in NH3' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: How many electrons are involved in the following half-reaction after it is balanced?  Cr2O72− + H+ + e− → Cr2+ + H2O
questions.explanation: First, balance the atoms in the equation: Cr2O72− + 14 H+ → 2 Cr2+ + 7 H2O Now, adjust the number of electrons to balance the charge. Currently, the left side has a charge of +12 (–2 from dichromate and +14 from protons). The right side has a charge of +4 (+2 from each chromium cation). To decrease the charge on the left side from +12 to +4, we should add 8 electrons: Cr2O72− + 14 H+ + 8 e− → 2 Cr2+ + 7 H2O
questions.short_reason: 'Balance atoms first, then charges!' 7 oxygens need 14 H+ for water. Cr goes from +6 to +2 (2 Cr = 8 electrons gained). 8 electrons needed.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: 2 electrons would only reduce one Cr by 2 oxidation states - not enough.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: 12 electrons would over-reduce - Cr doesn't go negative.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: 16 electrons is too many - would require even more negative Cr.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Oxidation–reduction Reactions: Explain why '8' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Lithium aluminum hydride (LiAlH4) is often used in laboratories because of its tendency to donate a hydride ion. Which of the following roles would lithium aluminum hydride likely play in a reaction?

options.C: Both a strong reducing agent and strong oxidizing agent
options.D: Neither a strong reducing agent nor a strong oxidizing agent

questions.explanation: Hydride ions are composed of a hydrogen nucleus with two electrons, thereby giving it a negative charge and a considerable tendency to donate electrons. LiAlH4 is therefore a strong reducing agent. Strong reducing agents tend to have metals or hydrides; strong oxidizing agents tend to have oxygen or a similarly electronegative element.
questions.short_reason: 'Hydride is H-minus!' With two electrons on hydrogen, LiAlH4 desperately wants to GIVE them away = strong reducing agent.

wrong_answer_explanations.B: Oxidizing agents TAKE electrons - hydride wants to GIVE electrons.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: A species can't be both - donating and accepting are opposite actions.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: LiAlH4 is one of the STRONGEST reducing agents in organic chemistry!

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Oxidation–reduction Reactions: Explain why 'Strong reducing agent only' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: What is the oxidation number of chlorine in NaClO?
questions.explanation: In NaClO (sodium hypochlorite), sodium carries its typical +1 charge, and oxygen carries its typical –2 charge. This means that the chlorine atom must carry a +1 charge in order to balance the overall charge of zero.
questions.short_reason: 'Na is +1, O is -2, Cl must balance!' +1 + Cl + (-2) = 0, so Cl = +1.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: -1 would be Cl in regular chlorides like NaCl - but oxygen changes things.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: 0 would mean elemental chlorine - but it's bonded here.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: +2 would require different formula stoichiometry.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Oxidation–reduction Reactions: Explain why '+1' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: The following electronic configurations represent elements in their neutral form. Which element is the strongest oxidizing agent?
questions.explanation: A strong oxidizing agent will be easily reduced, meaning that it will have a tendency to gain electrons. Atoms usually gain electrons if they are one or two electrons away from filling up their valence shell. (A) has a full 4s-orbital, meaning that it can only gain an electron if it gains an entire subshell. (B) has a stable, half-full 3d-orbital, so it is unlikely to pick up electrons unless it can gain five. (C) has only a single electron in the outer shell, which is more likely lost upon ionization. (D) would fill up its 4p-orbital by gaining one electron, so it is easily reduced.
questions.short_reason: 'One electron away from full shell!' Configuration ending in 4p5 needs just one more electron to complete the octet - perfect for reduction.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: 4s2 is a filled subshell - stable, doesn't eagerly accept electrons.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Half-filled 3d5 is stable - manganese doesn't easily accept more electrons.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: 4p1 is more likely to LOSE that electron than gain 5 more.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Oxidation–reduction Reactions: Explain why '1s22s22p63s23p64s23d104p5' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the correct net ionic reaction for the reaction of copper with silver(I) nitrate?

options.B: Cu + 2 Ag+ + 2 NO3− → Cu2+ + 2 NO3− + 2 Ag

questions.explanation: A net ionic equation represents each of the aqueous ions comprising the reactants and products as individual ions, instead of combining them as formula units. Thus, (A) is not a net ionic reaction. The term net means that the correct answer does not include any spectator ions (ions that do not participate in the reaction). In this reaction, nitrate (NO3−) remains unchanged. Therefore, (B) and (C) are eliminated.
questions.short_reason: 'Net ionic shows only what changes!' Spectator ions (NO3-) disappear. Cu loses electrons, 2 Ag+ gain them.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: This is the full equation, not net ionic - includes formula units.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: This shows complete ionic but includes spectators - not 'net.'
wrong_answer_explanations.C: This cancels to nothing - that's not a reaction!

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Oxidation–reduction Reactions: Explain why 'Cu + 2 Ag+ → Cu2+ + 2 Ag' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: One way to test for the presence of iron in solution is by adding potassium thiocyanate to the solution. The product when this reagent reacts with iron is FeSCN2+, which creates a dark red color in solution via the following net ionic equation:  Fe3+ + SCN– → FeSCN2+  How many grams of iron sulfate would be needed to produce 2 moles of FeSCN2+?
questions.explanation: What you are shown is a net ionic equation. If two moles of FeSCN are created, two moles of Fe3+ must be used because the mole ratio is 1:1. Iron sulfate has the formula Fe2(SO4)3 because sulfate has a charge of –2 and iron has a charge of +3 (based on the net ionic equation). Therefore, one mole of iron sulfate is needed to make two moles of iron for the reaction. The molar mass of iron sulfate is 2 × 55.8 g mol + 3 × 32.1 g mol + 12 × 16.0 g mol = 399.9 g mol This most closely matches answer (C). The most common error would be to calculate the amount of iron, which would be 111.6 g, (A).
questions.short_reason: 'Iron sulfate = Fe2(SO4)3 for Fe3+!' Need 1 mol to give 2 mol Fe3+. MW ≈ 400 g/mol. Answer: 400 g.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: 110 g is mass of 2 mol Fe atoms only - forgot the sulfate!
wrong_answer_explanations.B: 220 g might be using FeSO4 formula (wrong iron oxidation state).
wrong_answer_explanations.D: 500 g is too high - calculation error.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Oxidation–reduction Reactions: Explain why '400 g' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: During the assigning of oxidation numbers, which of the following elements would most likely be determined last?
questions.explanation: When assigning oxidation numbers, one starts with elements of known oxidation state first, and determines the oxidation state of the other elements by deduction. As a noble gas, argon, (A), will always have an oxidation state of 0. As a Group VIIA element, fluorine, (B), will have an oxidation state of 0 (by itself) or –1 (in a compound). As a Group IIA element, strontium, (C), will have an oxidation state of 0 (by itself) or +2 (in a compound). Like most transition metals, iridium, (D), can have various oxidation states, ranging from –3 to +8. Therefore, one would have to determine the oxidation states of other atoms in an iridium-containing compound to determine iridium’s oxidation number.
questions.short_reason: 'Transition metals are wild cards!' Iridium can have many oxidation states (-3 to +8) - determine it last after assigning known oxidation states.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Ar is always 0 (noble gas) - determined immediately.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: F is always -1 in compounds (or 0 alone) - determined immediately.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Sr is always +2 in compounds (or 0 alone) - determined immediately.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Oxidation–reduction Reactions: Explain why 'Ir' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: As methanol is converted to methanal, and then methanoic acid, the oxidation number of the carbon:
questions.explanation: The formula for methanol is H3COH, for methanal is HCHO, and for methanoic acid is HCOOH. If we assign oxidation numbers to carbon in each molecule, it starts at –2, then becomes 0, then becomes +2: In general, it is often easier to think of oxidation as a gain of bonds to oxygen (or a similarly electronegative element) or loss of bonds to hydrogen for organic compounds. Therefore, because the carbon is oxidized as one converts from an alcohol to an aldehyde to a carboxylic acid, the oxidation number must increase.
questions.short_reason: 'Alcohol to aldehyde to acid = oxidation!' Carbon gains bonds to oxygen (or loses bonds to hydrogen) = oxidation = increasing oxidation number.

wrong_answer_explanations.B: Decreasing oxidation number would mean REDUCTION - opposite of what happens.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: The oxidation number changes continuously in one direction - doesn't reverse.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Same issue - it only increases, doesn't decrease at any point.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Oxidation–reduction Reactions: Explain why 'increases.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: In the compound KH2PO4, which element has the highest oxidation number?
questions.explanation: Start with the atoms that have oxidation states of which you are certain. Potassium is a Group IA metal, and therefore must have an oxidation state of +1. Hydrogen is almost always +1, unless it is paired with a less electronegative element (which is not the case here). Oxygen is generally –2. Because there are four oxygens, they create a total negative charge of –8 which is partially balanced by two hydrogens (+2) and potassium (+1). Therefore, phosphorus has a +5 charge, making it the highest oxidation state.
questions.short_reason: 'Assign known oxidation states first!' K = +1, H = +1 (×2), O = -2 (×4). Total so far: +1 +2 -8 = -5. P must be +5 to balance.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: K is only +1, not the highest in this compound.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: H is +1, also not the highest.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: O is -2 (negative), not the highest positive oxidation number.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Oxidation–reduction Reactions: Explain why 'P' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: If a certain metal has multiple oxidation states, its acidity as an oxide generally increases as the oxidation state increases. Therefore, which of the following tungsten compounds is likely to be the strongest acid?
questions.explanation: Recall that oxygen has an oxidation state of –2. Therefore, in tungsten(IV) oxide, (A), tungsten has an oxidation state of +4. In tungsten(VI) oxide, (B), it has an oxidation state of +6. In tungsten(III) oxide, (C), it is +3. In tungsten pentoxide, (D), it is +5.
questions.short_reason: 'Higher oxidation state = more acidic oxide!' W in WO3 has +6 oxidation state (highest among choices), making it most acidic.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: WO2 has W in +4 state - less acidic than WO3.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: W2O3 has W in +3 state - least acidic of tungsten oxides.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: W2O5 has W in +5 state - less acidic than +6 in WO3.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Oxidation–reduction Reactions: Explain why 'WO3' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text:
Consider the following steps in the reaction between oxalic acid and chlorine:   Which of these steps, occurring in aqueous solution, is an example of a disproportionation reaction?
I. Cl2 + H2O → HOCl + Cl– + H+
II. H2C2O4 → H+ + HC2O4−
III. HOCl + HC2O4− → H2O + Cl− + 2 CO2
questions.explanation: Step I is a disproportionation reaction because chlorine starts with an oxidation state of 0 in the reactants and ends up with an oxidation state of +1 in HOCl and –1 as Cl–. In the other reactions, no element appears with different oxidation states in two different products. Therefore, only step I is a disproportionation reaction.
questions.short_reason: 'Same element, different products = disproportionation!' Cl2 becomes both HOCl (+1) and Cl- (-1). Chlorine oxidizes AND reduces itself!

wrong_answer_explanations.B: Step III has no disproportionation - each element only appears in one product form.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Only step I shows disproportionation - step III doesn't qualify.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Step II is just acid dissociation - no redox at all.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Oxidation–reduction Reactions: Explain why 'I only' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Potentiometry in an oxidation–reduction titration is analogous to performing an acid–base titration with a(n):
questions.explanation: Potentiometry refers to carrying out an oxidation–reduction titration with a voltmeter present to get precise readings of the reaction’s electromotive force (emf) to determine the endpoint. This is analogous to using a pH meter in an acid–base titration because it uses technology to get precise readings for plotting a titration curve. Indicators, as in (A) and (B), can be used in both acid–base and redox titrations, but provide a qualitative (rather than quantitative) analysis of the titration. Oxidizing and reducing agents are used in redox titrations, not acid–base titrations, eliminating (D).
questions.short_reason: 'Potentiometry = voltmeter, just like pH meter!' Both give quantitative readings for plotting titration curves instead of just color changes.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Acidic indicator gives qualitative color change, not quantitative data.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Basic indicator also gives qualitative color change.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Oxidizing agent is a reactant in redox titrations, not a measuring tool.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Oxidation–reduction Reactions: Explain why 'pH meter.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: After balancing the following oxidation–reduction reaction, what is the sum of the stoichiometric coefficients of all of the reactants and products?  S8 (s) + NO3− (aq) → SO32− (aq) + NO (g)
questions.explanation: Utilize the method described earlier to balance this redox reaction. The balanced half-reactions are: To get equal numbers of electrons in each half-reaction, the oxidation half-reaction will have to be multiplied by 3, and the reduction half-reaction will have to be multiplied by 32: This makes the overall reaction: 3 S8 + 32 NO3− + 8 H2O → 24 SO32− + 32 NO + 16 H+ The sum of the stoichiometric coefficients is therefore: 3 + 32 + 8 + 24 + 32 + 16 = 115.
questions.short_reason: 'Balance half-reactions, then combine!' After multiplying to equal electrons: 3 + 32 + 8 + 24 + 32 + 16 = 115 total coefficients.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: 4 is way too small - even the H2O coefficient is bigger!
wrong_answer_explanations.B: 50 is missing several species or using wrong coefficients.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: 91 is close but has a calculation error somewhere.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Oxidation–reduction Reactions: Explain why '115' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: An assay is performed to determine the gold content in a supply of crushed ore. One method for pulling gold out of ore is to react it in a concentrated cyanide (CN–) solution. The equation is provided below:  Au + NaCN + O2 + H2O → Na[Au(CN)2] + NaOH  An indicator is used during this reaction, and approximately 100 mL of a 2 M NaCN solution is used to reach the endpoint. How many moles of Au are present in the crushed ore?
questions.explanation: First, balance the chemical equation: 4 Au + 8 NaCN + O2 + 2 H2O → 4 Na[Au(CN)2] + 4 NaOH Now, determine the number of moles of NaCN used in the reaction: If 0.2 mol NaCN are used in the reaction, then 0.2 mol NaCN × 4 mol Au 8 mol NaCN = 0.1 mol Au is oxidized.
questions.short_reason: 'Balance, then use stoichiometry!' 4 Au : 8 NaCN ratio. 0.2 mol NaCN × (4/8) = 0.1 mol Au.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: 0.01 mol is 10× too small - ratio calculation error.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: 0.02 mol uses wrong stoichiometric ratio.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: 0.20 mol would mean 1:1 ratio with NaCN - not correct.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Oxidation–reduction Reactions: Explain why '0.10 mol' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Rusting occurs due to the oxidation–reduction reaction of iron with environmental oxygen: 4 Fe (s) + 3 O2 (g) → 2 Fe2O3 (s)  Some metals cannot react with oxygen in this fashion.  Which of the following best explains why iron can?

options.A: Iron has a more positive reduction potential than those metals, making it more likely to donate electrons to oxygen.
options.B: Iron has a more positive reduction potential than those metals, making it more likely to accept electrons from oxygen.
options.C: Iron has a less positive reduction potential than those metals, making it more likely to donate electrons to oxygen.
options.D: Iron has a less positive reduction potential than those metals, making it more likely to accept electrons from oxygen.

questions.explanation: In the oxidation–reduction reaction of a metal with oxygen, the metal will be oxidized (donate electrons) and oxygen will be reduced (accept electrons). This fact allows us to immediately eliminate (B) and (D). A species with a higher reduction potential is more likely to be reduced, and a species with a lower reduction potential is more likely to be oxidized. Based on the information in the question, iron is oxidized more readily than those metals; this means that iron has a lower reduction potential.
questions.short_reason: 'Lower reduction potential = better at oxidizing!' Iron has less positive (more negative) E°red than noble metals, so it gives up electrons more easily to oxygen.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: More positive E°red means more likely to be REDUCED, not oxidized.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Iron is oxidized (loses electrons), not reduced (gains electrons).
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Less positive E°red means more likely to be OXIDIZED, not reduced.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Electrochemistry: Explain why 'Iron has a less positive reduction potential than those metals, making it more likely to donate electrons to oxygen.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Given the following standard reduction potentials:  Zn 2 + + 2 e − → Zn E red ∘ = − 0.763 V Ag + + e − → Ag E red ∘ = + 0.337 V  What is the standard electromotive force of the following reaction?  Zn2+ + 2 Ag → 2 Ag+ + Zn
questions.explanation: To determine the standard electromotive force of a cell, simply subtract the standard reduction potentials of the two electrodes. In this case, the cathode is zinc because it is being reduced; the anode is silver because it is being oxidized. Thus, E°cell = E°red,cathode − E°red,anode = − 0.763 − 0.337 = − 1.10 V While we must multiply the silver half-reaction by two to balance electrons, the actual value for the reduction potential does not change. Remember that the standard reduction potential is determined by the identity of the electrode, not the amount of it present.
questions.short_reason: 'E°cell = E°cathode - E°anode!' Zn is reduced (cathode), Ag is oxidized (anode). E°cell = -0.763 - 0.337 = -1.1 V.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: -2.2 V would require doubling something - but we don't double reduction potentials.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: +1.1 V would be correct if the reaction were reversed (Ag+ + Cu → ...).
wrong_answer_explanations.D: +2.2 V has both wrong sign and wrong magnitude.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Electrochemistry: Explain why '–1.1 V' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Consider the following data:  Hg 2 + + 2 e − → Hg E red ∘ = + 0.85 V Cu + + e − → Cu E red ∘ = + 0.52 V Zn 2 + + 2 e − → Zn E red ∘ = − 0.76 V Al 3 + + 3 e − → Al E red ∘ = − 1.66 V  The anode of a certain galvanic cell is composed of copper. Which of the metals from the data table can be used at the cathode, assuming equal concentrations of the two electrolyte solutions?
questions.explanation: Oxidation occurs at the anode, and reduction occurs at the cathode. Because Cu is the anode, it must be oxidized. The reduction potential of the cathode cannot be less than that of the anode for a galvanic cell. Therefore, mercury, (A), must be the cathode. In a concentration cell, the same material is used as both the cathode and anode; however, this question assumes equal concentrations. If both electrolyte solutions have the same concentration, there will be no oxidation–reduction reaction and, therefore, no anode or cathode. This eliminates (B).
questions.short_reason: 'Galvanic needs positive E°cell!' Cu is oxidized (anode), so cathode needs HIGHER E°red. Only Hg (+0.85) beats Cu (+0.52).

wrong_answer_explanations.B: Same metal for both electrodes needs different concentrations - not given here.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Zn has E°red = -0.76, LOWER than Cu - would give negative E°cell.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Al has E°red = -1.66, even lower - would give even more negative E°cell.
