learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Electrochemistry: Explain why 'Hg' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text:
An electrolytic cell is filled with water. Which of the following will move toward the cathode of such a cell?
I. H+ ions
II. O2– ions
III. Electrons
questions.explanation: In an electrolytic cell, ionic compounds are broken up into their constituents; the cations (positively charged ions) migrate toward the cathode, and the anions (negatively charged ions) migrate toward the anode. In this case, the cations are H+ ions (protons), so option I is correct. Electrons flow from anode to cathode in all types of cells, meaning that option III is also correct. Option II is incorrect for two reasons. First, it is unlikely that the anions in any cell would be O2– rather than OH–. Second, and more significantly, these anions would flow to the anode, not the cathode.
questions.short_reason: 'Opposites attract!' Positive H+ ions go toward negative cathode. Electrons always flow from anode to cathode.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Electrons also move to cathode - not just H+ ions.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: O2- would go to ANODE (positive electrode), not cathode.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Electrons DO move toward cathode - statement III is true.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Electrochemistry: Explain why 'I and III only' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: If the value of E°cell is known, what other data is needed to calculate ΔG°?
questions.explanation: This answer comes directly from the equation relating Gibbs free energy and E°cell. ΔG° = −nFE°cell, where n is the number of moles of electrons transferred and F is the Faraday constant, 96 , 485 C mol e − . To determine n, one must look at the balanced half-reactions occurring in the oxidation–reduction reaction.
questions.short_reason: 'ΔG° = -nFE°cell' - need n!' To find ΔG°, we need the number of moles of electrons transferred, which comes from the half-reactions.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Keq relates to ΔG° differently - through RT ln K equation.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Q is for non-standard conditions - we want standard ΔG°.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Temperature is in the Nernst equation, not the standard ΔG° equation.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Electrochemistry: Explain why 'Half-reactions of the cells' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following compounds is LEAST likely to be found in the salt bridge of a galvanic cell?
questions.explanation: Salt bridges contain inert electrolytes. Ionic compounds, such as (A), (C), and (D), are known to be strong electrolytes because they completely dissociate in solution. (B) cannot be considered an electrolyte because its atoms are covalently bonded and will not dissociate in aqueous solution. (B) and (C) may appear similar, but there is an important distinction to be made. (C) implies that Mg2+ and SO32− are the final, dissociated ionic constituents, while (B) implies that neutral SO3 would have to be dissolved in solution.
questions.short_reason: 'Salt bridges need ions!' SO3 is a covalent oxide that doesn't dissociate into ions in solution - useless as a salt bridge electrolyte.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: NaCl dissociates completely into Na+ and Cl- - excellent electrolyte.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: MgSO3 gives Mg2+ and SO32- ions - good electrolyte.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: NH4NO3 gives NH4+ and NO3- ions - also good electrolyte.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Electrochemistry: Explain why 'SO3' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text:
If the surface area of electrode material in an electrochemical cell is tripled, what else is necessarily tripled?
I. E°cell
II. Current
III. Keq
questions.explanation: Potential, as measured by E°cell, is dependent only on the identity of the electrodes and not the amount present. Similarly, the equilibrium constant depends only on the identity of the electrolyte solutions and the temperature. However, as the electrode material is increased, the surface area participating in oxidation–reduction reactions is increased and more electrons are released, making statement II correct.
questions.short_reason: 'More surface = more reaction sites!' More electrode area means more electrons can be released per second = more current. E° and Keq don't change.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: E°cell depends only on electrode IDENTITY, not amount.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: E°cell definitely doesn't change with surface area.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Keq is a thermodynamic constant - doesn't depend on electrode amount.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Electrochemistry: Explain why 'II only' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following can alter the emf of an electrochemical cell?

options.B: The length of the wire connecting the half-cells
options.C: The overall size of the battery
options.D: The temperature of the solutions in the half-cells

questions.explanation: E°cell is dependent upon the change in free energy of the system through the equation RT ln Keq = nFE°cell. The temperature, T, appears in this equation; thus, a change in temperature will impact the E°cell.
questions.short_reason: 'Temperature appears in Nernst equation!' RT/nF shows temperature affects cell potential. Other physical dimensions don't matter for emf.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Mass of electrodes affects current capacity, not emf.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Wire length affects resistance, not standard emf.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Battery size affects capacity and current, not voltage.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Electrochemistry: Explain why 'The temperature of the solutions in the half-cells' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements could be true about a Na–Cd cell, based on the information below?  Na + + e − → Na E red ∘ = − 2.71 V Cd 2 + + 2 e − → Cd E red ∘ = − 0.40 V

options.A: It is a galvanic cell, and sodium is the cathode.
options.B: It is an electrolytic cell, and cadmium is the anode.
options.C: It is a galvanic cell, with E°cell = 3.11 V.
options.D: It is an electrolytic cell, with E°cell = −3.11 V.

questions.explanation: If this were a galvanic cell, the species with the more positive reduction potential (cadmium) would be reduced. The cathode is always reduced in an electrochemical cell, so sodium could not be the cathode in such a galvanic cell, eliminating (A). Sodium would be the cathode in an electrolytic cell, however, which would make cadmium the anode. Thus, the answer is (B). Note that we do not have to determine E°cell because we already know the answer. However, the E°cell would be −2.71 − (−0.40) = −2.31 V for an electrolytic cell, and +2.31 V for a galvanic cell, eliminating (C) and (D).
questions.short_reason: 'Electrolytic reverses natural direction!' Na has lower E°red than Cd, so naturally Cd reduces. Electrolytic forces Na reduction, making Cd the anode.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: In galvanic, Na would be ANODE (oxidized), Cd would be cathode.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: E°cell calculation: |-2.71 - (-0.40)| = 2.31 V, not 3.11 V.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Same calculation error - E°cell is ±2.31 V, not ±3.11 V.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Electrochemistry: Explain why 'It is an electrolytic cell, and cadmium is the anode.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following expressions correctly describes the relationship between standard electromotive force and standard change in free energy?

options.B: E cell ∘ = n F R T ln K eq
options.C: E cell ∘ = − R T n F ln K eq

questions.explanation: There are only two equations involving standard change in free energy in electrochemical cells: ΔG° = −nFE°cell and ΔG° = –RT ln Keq. Substituting E°cell = E°red,cathode − E°red,anode into the first equation and distributing the negative sign gives (D). (A) would be the opposite of ΔG°. Setting the two equations equal to each other, we get RT ln Keq = nFE°cell. Solving for E°cell, we get E cell ∘ = R T n F ln K eq , which is the opposite of (B). (C) incorrectly solves the algebra.
questions.short_reason: 'Distribute the negative!' ΔG° = -nFE°cell = -nF(E°red,cathode - E°red,anode) = nF(E°red,anode - E°red,cathode).

wrong_answer_explanations.A: This is -ΔG°, not ΔG° - sign is wrong.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: This incorrectly solves for E°cell from the ΔG° equation.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: The negative is in the wrong place in this rearrangement.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Electrochemistry: Explain why 'ΔG° = nF(E°red,anode − E°red,cathode)' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following choices is indicative of a spontaneous reaction, assuming standard conditions?

options.C: The cell is a concentration cell.

questions.explanation: A spontaneous electrochemical reaction has a negative ΔG. Using the equation ΔG° = –RT ln Keq, Keq > 1 would result in ln Keq > 0, which means ΔG° < 0. A negative electromotive force, (A), or equilibrium state, (B), would not correspond to a spontaneous reaction. Concentration cells can be spontaneous; however, if the concentration cell had reached equilibrium, it would cease to be a spontaneous reaction, eliminating (C). When an answer choice may be true, but does not have to be—it is the wrong answer on Test Day.
questions.short_reason: 'Keq > 1 means products favored = spontaneous!' From ΔG° = -RT ln K, Keq > 1 gives negative ΔG° = spontaneous.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Negative E°cell means NONspontaneous, not spontaneous.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Q = Keq means equilibrium - no net reaction, not spontaneous progress.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Concentration cells CAN be spontaneous but aren't NECESSARILY so.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Electrochemistry: Explain why 'Keq > 1' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: For a cell with the following half-reactions:  Anode: SO2 + 2 H2O → SO42− + 4 H+ + 2 e−  Cathode: Pd2+ + 2 e− → Pd  How would decreasing the pH of the solution inside the cell affect the electromotive force (emf)?

options.B: The emf would remain the same.

questions.explanation: A change in pH has a direct correlation to the hydrogen ion (H+) concentration. Decreasing the pH increases the H+ concentration, which means the concentration of products has increased in the oxidation of sulfur dioxide. This means it would be harder to liberate electrons, thus decreasing the emf. One could also view this decrease in oxidation potential as an increase in reduction potential. If E°red,anode increases, then E°cell must decrease according to E°cell = E°red,cathode − E°red,anode.
questions.short_reason: 'More H+ = Le Chatelier shift left!' Increasing product concentration shifts equilibrium backward, reducing the emf from the anode half-reaction.

wrong_answer_explanations.B: Adding product to one half-cell definitely affects emf - not constant.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Increasing product pushes equilibrium backward, DECREASING emf.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: The cell will still function - emf just decreases, doesn't become zero.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Electrochemistry: Explain why 'The emf would decrease.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: An electrolytic cell necessarily has:
questions.explanation: An electrolytic cell is nonspontaneous. Therefore, the ΔG° must be positive and E°cell must be negative, eliminating (B) and (D). The change in entropy may be positive or negative, depending on the species involved, eliminating (A). According to the equation ΔG° = –RT ln Keq, Keq < 1 would result in ln Keq < 0, which means ΔG° > 0.
questions.short_reason: 'Electrolytic = nonspontaneous = Keq < 1!' Positive ΔG° means products are less favored than reactants at equilibrium.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Entropy change can be either positive or negative - not determined by cell type.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: ΔG° must be POSITIVE for nonspontaneous electrolytic cells.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: E°cell must be NEGATIVE for electrolytic cells.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Electrochemistry: Explain why 'Keq < 1' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the best explanation for the fact that a larger mass of electrodes are required for lead–acid batteries, as compared to other batteries, to produce a certain current?

options.A: The lead–acid electrolyte, sulfuric acid, is diprotic and incompletely dissociates in solution.
options.B: The energy density of lead–acid electrodes is higher than that of other batteries.
options.C: The electrolytes in other batteries less readily dissociate than those of lead–acid batteries.
options.D: The energy density of lead–acid electrodes is lower than that of other batteries.

questions.explanation: Compared to other cell types, lead–acid batteries have a characteristically low energy density, (D). While (A) is a true statement, the incomplete dissociation of sulfuric acid does not fully explain the low energy density of lead–acid batteries. (C) is likely to be an opposite; the more easily the electrodes dissociate, the easier it is to carry out oxidation–reduction reactions with them.
questions.short_reason: 'Lead-acid = heavy but cheap!' Low energy density means you need more mass to store the same energy compared to other battery types.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Sulfuric acid dissociation doesn't explain why more mass is needed.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Higher energy density would mean LESS mass needed - opposite!
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Other electrolytes dissociating less readily would help lead-acid, not hurt it.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Electrochemistry: Explain why 'The energy density of lead–acid electrodes is lower than that of other batteries.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following best describes why over-charging a Ni–Cd battery is not detrimental?

options.A: The energy density of a Ni–Cd battery is high, so it can store more charge than other batteries per its mass.
options.B: The electrodes of a Ni–Cd battery can discharge through the circuit when they are fully charged.
options.C: The Ni–Cd battery will stop accepting electrons from an outside source when its electrodes are recharged.
options.D: Ni–Cd batteries have a high surge current and can dissipate the overcharge before damage can occur to electrodes.

questions.explanation: During the recharge cycle, Ni–Cd cells will accept current from an outside source until the Cd and NiO(OH) electrodes are pure; at this point, the reaction will stop because Cd(OH)2 runs out and no more electrons can be accepted. (A) and (B) are both true statements, but they fail to explain why overcharging the battery (continuing to try to run current into the battery even when the electrodes are reverted to their original state) is not a problem with Ni–Cd batteries. Finally, surge current refers to the initial burst of current seen in some batteries; once charged, the surge current will not increase even if the power source continues to be run because no additional charge will be stored on the electrodes, eliminating (D).
questions.short_reason: 'Ni-Cd batteries stop charging when full!' Once electrodes are fully reduced/oxidized, they can't accept more electrons - natural overcharge protection.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: High energy density relates to capacity, not overcharge protection.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Discharging through the circuit is normal operation, not overcharge protection.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: High surge current relates to power delivery, not overcharge handling.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT General Chemistry - Electrochemistry: Explain why 'The Ni–Cd battery will stop accepting electrons from an outside source when its electrodes are recharged.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.
